title: A 45-year-old woman with dermatomyositis
clinical_history: A 45-year-old woman presented with a 3-month history of progressive muscle weakness and skin rash. She reported difficulty getting up from a seated position, climbing stairs, and performing daily activities due to muscle weakness. The patient also complained of a characteristic heliotrope rash on her eyelids and a Gottron's papule on her knuckles.

nprs.affected_area: proximal muscle weakness (shoulders, hips, and thighs)

aggrevating_factors: physical activity, especially those that involve lifting, bending, or overhead reaching
picture: a 24-hour picture showing difficulty getting up from a seated position and performing daily activities
easing_factors: rest, physical therapy, and corticosteroid treatment
past_history: history of autoimmune disorders in the family
medical_history: recent diagnosis of dermatomyositis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia
medications: corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and pain management medications
personal_history: married with two children, works part-time as an administrative assistant, and enjoys gardening and reading in her free time
imaging: MRI of the thighs and shoulders showing evidence of muscle inflammation and damage
